Hovey — 3
Pietro Nennl, is one of the most colorful and interesting figures in the
Chamber. If you come clockwise around the bank from the Communist benches the
next group is occupied by deputies of Nenni1a Partito Socialists Italiano.
Nenni himself sits about halfway up the bank in one of the last seats of the
Socialist section — Just across the aisle from his bitter political enemies,
the Social Democrats.
Nennl is a broad, stocky man of 63, with a fringe of sandy hair and
thick-rimmed glasses. He has the reputation of being one of the most effective
orators in the Chamber. He has a friendly appearance and, in fact, is liked
personally by men who differ with him sharply In politics.
When you watch Nenni in operation in the Chamber it is difficult to
imagine him as the stooge of Togliattl or anyone else. But it should not be
forgotten that never once has Nennl really wavered from the Communist line since
he struck his so-called “unity of action* pact with Togliatti.
Neither should it be forgotten that sitting not far from Nennl in the
Chamber are create Lizzadri and Glusto To Hoy, two men regarded by Italian
democrats as virtual Communist agents operating within the socialist party to
keep it on the kremlin track.
Continuing to move clockwise in the Chamber, you find in the next section
Giuseppe Baragat and his Social Democrats, now reduced to 19 seats, and the
Republican party, which now has only five.
Saragat is a tall, handsome man who looks like our former secretary of
state, Dean Aoheaon, without the mustache. Saragat is restless during debate
and seldom occupies on© seat for very long. He has not yet recovered from the
shock of the 195,3 elections, when his party not only failed to gain at Nennl1 s
expense, but lost 600,000 votes and 14 Chamber seats from its 1948 showing.
Best known of the five Republican deputies is Randolfo Pacciardi, minister
of defense in Pe Gasper! cabinets and highly regarded by both President Eisen¬
hower and the present supreme allied commander in Europe, Gen. Alfred M.
Gruenther.
Pacciardi was a militant anti-fascist in the Mussolini era who soent
years of exile in America, as commander of the Italian anti-fascist Garibaldi
brigade in the Spanish civil war, he learned — and has never forgotten — the
agonizing difficulties of trying to cooperate with the Communists In any
common effort.
Because of his vigorous anti-fascism jgd anti-communism, Pacciardi has
been bitterly and constantly attacked by the two extremes. But you get the
impression that this husky, blunt-talking veteran of both shooting and politi¬
cal wars would follow wherever principal led him, regardless of the cost to
himself or his dwindling party. His friends would say that is why Pacclardl
swung his five Republican votes behind the Fanfanl government in January while
Saragat persuaded his party to vote no.
The most successful Italian party by far la this post-world war II
period has been, of course, the Christian Democrats. They still hold 262
seats in the center and right-center of the Chamber — 44 more than the Commun¬
ists and Nenni Socialists combined.
Sitting high up on the bank in the exact center of the chamber is the man
sho, more than any other, fashioned this success. He is the man who for eight
postwar years headed the government and virtually became wMr. Italy, * so far
as Americans wore concerned.
